text: Vint Cerf when you're called the father
of the Internet a title I noticed that
you don't reject you're very comfortable
with that well except that I have
repeatedly pointed out that there are
more than there's more than one father
of the Internet there are a number of us
say that had a lot to do with it Bob
Kahn and I did the original design but
most people want to know who's the
mother of the Internet
well among others it could get kind of
racy well my son wants to know he's his
brother to the Internet what did you do
who were you back then and when was back
then well back then was really in 1968
the priests the network that preceded
the internet was called the ARPANET and
a bunch of us were working on that I was
at UCLA as a graduate student and
working on a machine that you see in the
picture there called the Sigma seven
connected to the first node of the
ARPANET the first wide-area packet
switching Network and that was a big
challenge just to get that to work and I
wasn't the author of it I was a graduate
student at the time but subsequent to
the success of this packet switched
ARPANET Bob Kahn and I began working on
connecting networks to each other and
there were radio networks satellite
networks ARPANET and that was the
internet problem and he and I designed
what's called the tcp/ip protocols and
those are the fundamental protocols and
make the internet work and and who are
you working for in other words who
wanted you doing this kind of work the
Defense Advanced Research Projects
Agency funded the work on ARPANET funded
the work on internet and many subsequent
networking related projects this is all
in expectation that computers would be
important for command and control and
that you'd have to use them in mobile
vehicles and aircraft ships at sea as
well as fixed installations and that's
why we needed radio and satellite as
well as wireline so is it inaccurate to
say that in a very real sense of it
initially was part of to seem to be part
of a weapon system
I'm sorry part of it it was inaccurate
to say that initially your work
was seen to be at least auxiliary to a
weapons system not weapon system now in
fact the ARPANET project the one in this
picture you're seeing there was all
about resource sharing the ARPA the
Advanced Research Projects Agency was
funding work at about a dozen
universities around the country in MIT
and Stanford Carnegie Mellon on
artificial intelligence and advanced
computer science and every year the the
schools would say well you have to get
us another world-class computer the
latest thing this year oh we can't do
world-class research and even ARPA
couldn't afford to buy a multi-million
dollar machine every year for all 12 of
the schools I said we're going to build
a network and you can share we will
connect the machines to each other and
you can share software and computing
capability so it started out as a
resource sharing experiment but it was
understood that if it worked it could be
the basis for a serious piece of command
and control capability that was I would
say less weapons orientation than simply
management did you given that you were
describing something to to your
benefactors your bosses that didn't
exist was that a hard sell did were you
were you imagining something that they
couldn't quite imagine or picture no no
no the people that initiated the program
were geeks just like we were they
understand that is talked about they
wouldn't have put money into it if they
hadn't appreciated it the details of
course evolved over time but the
understanding that getting computers to
interact with each other to collect data
to analyze and make information
available to everyone was an extremely
powerful concept and it was one that
they inherently understood everybody got
it everybody got it the only question
was can you make it work and of course
that's what engineers do they take
science fiction and they turn it into
reality
